column5: Compared to the crap I was fishing walleyes in on Sunday and Monday, these days ainâ€™t too bad for a boat ride lol
I have a new/old float reel that's jealous of all the muskie fishing I've been doing.Â  Haven't even thought about a steelhead this fall.

I recently bought a place on Pigeon, been hitting the lake hard, friend got 1 in boat, couple lost, few follows but been getting stumped last 2 weeks.Â  Only I 5 lb walleye to show for my efforts, hitting Pigeon again tomorrow with some new Medussas

keep at it! Don't get discouraged. As the water gets below 50 (which it is) the bite can be pretty tough. Pigeon is a great lake but when it comes to musky, being skunked is always something that can happen, even on a great lake.
Ain't that the truthÂ  LOL
SPOKEN BY THE MASTER
Wrong species, but the rod going off was nice.Â  Â 42in on the tape.Â  Â Ate a 13in Grandma in fire tiger down 18 over 36. ]
Purty fish Bill, really bright colours.
Nice one Bill.Â  Keep up the hard work
nice pike! And no offence to pike...but man am I disappointedÂ when the rod goes off and IÂ bring in a pike. Then again, I have never caught a 42 inch pike...maybe I would be ok with that!

Few years back we had a full week during the third week of November when temps hit highs as highÂ of 21C for several of those days.Â  it was calm, SW breeze if anything and mostly bluebird.Â  For 6 days straight I took a skunking running late season patterns on the St. Lawrence.Â  On the 7th day Brenda joined me and she caught a small fish from the weeds.Â  About a week later, guide John Anderson on the Ottawa posts that he'd putting clients on plenty of fish... all casting... all in real shallow, like less than 3-4fow if I recall.Â  So you've got two choices... grind the fall pattern or, think like "spring."Â  And when you think like spring you think muskies (baitfish and other fish too) are drawn to the warming, shoreline waters.Â  In fall I'd think it takes some substantial warmth, such as really high heat and sun or, long periods of it like a heatwave pattern, but after the first initial days of it, the skis may just settle in and begin feeding shallow. Fall is the toughest time to fish, but the rewards are great not just with the catch, but in trying toÂ figureÂ it out too.
I think I remember that.. something about working real shallow and inside weed edges late year. Something to exploreÂ for sure

I had a similar experience with November musky a few years ago in November. Beautiful sunny day with t-shirt weather by noon. I had a couple of follows and one muskie caught on top water - all in 3-5 feet of water. I trolled deeper water for several hours with no sign of life! I got one last week just after that really hot day (+24 here in Mississauga), fishing LCS with a warm wind and +12 for most of the day. I didn't see any other people get a fish from shore that day (at least not in the area I fished) and they only difference there was that they were letting their baits drop to the bottom after the cast, and I was reeling right away, keeping my bait up higher.

After seeing all the insane bait balls I have been for the past few weeks, it's hard to even think about going into 3ft of water. Â  Back at it Thurs/Fri and probably Sat (with the top up, calls for rain). Â  I'm waiting for that big heavy to make an appearance.
Good luck Bill! I'm heading out tonight after work and doing the shore musky nightshift on LSC!

Same experiences here seeing themÂ shallow late year. I just can't remember if that coinciding with aÂ warm front of not.Â Maybe it did. My logs are spotty or none existent lol I think it was 2016 that IÂ read up on the late season shallow water bite on the Ottawa. I remember becauseÂ I tried to apply it in the kawartha's on my last trip thatÂ year. We broke ice to get out so must of been early Dec. I asked my friend to take the wheel while cruising out of the shallows so I could stand on the deck andÂ scope for fish cruising shallow spooked by the boat. I ended up seeing a few. We then pulled off the edge and I started working it casting way up top and got one nice one to bite (on one of my longest figure 8's ever) Last warm spell I was on gbay fishing on the saturday (day 4 of the warm front - Nov 7), we didn't get any bites but did see two fish off shallow structure throughout the day.Â The water temps only increased 1-2 degrees through the course of that day. One of thoseÂ fish wasÂ pretty hot to go it seemed, we kind of blew our chance unfortunately. But she was shallow. I think there's a few patterns that go this time of the year.Â  Gotta try it all. Always nice to get rewarded after noodling over what to do out there. Only thing with musky is the rewards on the big waters aren't plentiful enough!!
Thanks man!Â  I gotta make it down to LSC and experience that craziness myself  Â  Goodluck out there
It's not even muskie fishing in the sense of muskie fishing, its glorified pike fishing. lol. Fun nonetheless.

Bunk I heard you faired pretty well in a tournament out east a couple of weeks ago. Your competition that I think finished 2nd is a bit of a content creator and he posted the leader board and I was like â€œhey I know who that isâ€ lol

First Muskie Capital Cup. 35 Anglers. 13 teams. 9 day tournament. Some solid guys fishing, a number of guides and one fella in the tourney even hired a guide.Â  We did GREAT!Â  Two guys I fished with are bigger muskie nuts than I am with many more years and skis under their beltsÂ but, I think I was brought on board because the tourney is in the fall and that's only when I muskie fish, and do well at nettin' tanks during that time.Â  Luckily my choices and rod while casting and trolling brought our three biggest fish in the boat, and 3 of the 5 biggest in the tourney.Â  So yeah, we won the tournament and will have to do it again next year.
Congrats! From the numbers I saw posted you guys caught some tanks!

Didn't see a fish on LSC yesterday. It was fairly cold with temperatures below zero when we started fishing after dark. It definitely wasn't fun dealing with iced guides in the darkness, but we continue to fish hard sunrise to sunset. Plenty of guys out on the water and from shore, but I didnt see anyone connect! I've already heard that this morning was great...I guess were were a day early! A fun day overall, but ended up with a localÂ deciding to put a big dent in the side of my car with their foot...not sure if he didn't like outsiders in "his spot" or they didn'tÂ like my little Mazda parking in GM territory!Â ğŸ˜ Â Pretty unfortunate as my past experiences there meeting other muskie nuts on shore has been so positive and there has always been a great sense of comradery.
Fawkers eh Clive! Few seasons back my "Chev" over in Degen country took two fists sized dents while out muskie fishing too.Â  Fishing In"fury"ating.
Well we've got the pike dialed in on Gbay apparently.Â  18 down over 40ft on a 13 in grandma again.Â  Â Had the heater and the top up.

If there is any weather pattern that has ever spelled doom for me, it is a warming trend in late fall. Of course I have a 2 day trip booked to Pigeon for later this week ..right in the middle of a warming trend. Over the years I recall many a gorgeous late fall day on the water...and what I also recall is the fishing sucked. I would love to hear any success stories under these conditions if you have them...and would really love to hear what worked. If you also just feel the need to tell me, "yes...you are doomed" that is fine too.

You"ll do way better on the water then on the couch at home. Just keep positive, get out there and get them. Over the years seen it go both ways! Will be fishing for them on the O.R. every day as well so if it makes you feel any better you won't be alone  Good luck!

I'd suggest you study the solunar charts and plan to be on your best spot(s) throwing confidence baits during any peak times. The rest of the time just cover water and conserve your energy/ intensity for those peak times. Maybe search for a few new spots to add to your peak activity milk run.
It won't do much for water temps, fish those late fall patterns like you usually would.Â  Â Hopefully Gbay coughs up a big one for me.

I'm headed to the French River area, I'm counting on a late day bite, solunar major is late afternoon, the water will be nice and warm by then on my spots!  Attitude is everything in muskie fishing. Start with a positive one!

My experience has been it can be tough. But the warm spell is a week long, so they might adjust and start moving. Also they gotta eat at some point in a week I'd think! But who knows? For other species...Â sometimes warm days/few degree hike in water temps can trigger feed mode... but my experience with musky has been tougher days and short windows. But that is pretty much musky fishing in general in the fall. No banger days for myself however during the warm spells. I'm fishing it too. Just gonna give it a solid go and enjoy the nice weather!
lots of positive attitudes...love it. Will fish deep water....figure those fish less affected by what is going on above the water
I always say if you can't fish with confidence, fish with determination.Â  Just chuck n' wind lol.
Ultimately, it comes down to this....MUSKIES SUCK!
well that is one warmÂ day out of the way. We fish Friday and Saturday this week. If today sucked, and tomorrow does too, the fish should be ready to go by Friday!
Skunk out ofÂ HH today, but that's Gbay muskie fishing for ya.Â  Weather was mint!Â  Back at it tomorrow, going to try a different section of water.
You and I know that if you hook one it's going to be a beauty.Â  I'm deciding on either Upper Niagara or St.Clair Saturday.Â  Confidence is a little low now catching 1 in the last 4 trips.

And that's the allure of Gbay.Â  You've got a legitimate shot at the next world record.Â  Â The fish out there are just built differently.Â  Â I know what the pros are talking about when they mention the mental game, I haven't netted a muskie since the 29th of Sept lol.Â  Â Maybe I'll go find those giant schools of bait fish and do some jigging today.

for me...upper niagara is 3 hours driving round trip, and St Clair is 6 hours driving round trip. St. Clair is where I go! Used to fish Upper Niagara 15 years ago but found the fish per hour fishing ratioÂ waaay better on St C even when you factor in the drive!

The driving is sometimes the difference maker and this weekend itâ€™s probably going to be Niagara. Â Not much boat traffic on Niagara and getting no action the past few times on St.Clair has me needing a change of scenery. Â Your right Bill about GBay. Â Who says there isnâ€™t a 80lber cruising around in there lol. Â Just make sure you got a good strong rod holder when trolling in late November.
yes... a skunking on L St. C does hurt a lot more than a skunking closer to home! And if you only have a partial day available rather than a marathon, this also pushes me towards upper n
doing better than me bill, i havent caught a musky larger than a snot rocket since 2017 on the bay! lol
Another 10hrs today and nada.Â  Â Tomorrow I'm breaking out the big rubber.
soooo dedicated.
Cause Bill has got dreams of replacing Ken Oâ€™Brians big record.
Maybe downsizing your gear would work better "Â Ken O`Brien, a 28-year-old angler from Toronto, was trolling for walleyes with a 4-inch Countdown Rapala when he hooked the fish.Â  "
Or being a fisherman who fishes a few times a year

I should probably just start trolling harnesses for walleye in the spring, I'm guessing more muskies are caught that way then any other lol Put another few hours on the Bay today, went shallow found some weeds and about a 35in pike who inhaled a Bulldawg.Â  Â No muskies.Â  Â Back at it this weekend.
I may hit GBay tomorrow and cast some Shadzilla's. Definitely feels unproductive heading out here, but you always have a chance of big one. Struck out on Pigeon the other week.
Dan, at least the scenery is nice
